translated: The SÅ«tra on the Differentiation of Karmic Retribution Spoken by the Buddha for the Elder Åšuka
Translated by Gautama Dharma-jÃ±Ä, Prefect of Yangchuan Prefecture of the Sui Dynasty
Thus have I heard. Once, the Buddha was dwelling in the Jeta Grove of AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the country of ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, the Buddha told the elder Åšuka, son of DÄ«ti,
Elder Åšuka!
I will explain to you the Dharma door of the differentiation of good and evil karmic retributions.
You should listen attentively and contemplate it well!
At that time, Åšuka addressed the Buddha, saying:
Yes, World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to listen!
The Buddha told Åšuka:
All sentient beings are bound by karma, rely on karma, and revolve according to their own karma.
For this reason, there are differences of superior, middling, and inferior.ğŸ”½There are karmas that can cause sentient beings to obtain a short life span as retribution;
there are karmas that can cause sentient beings to obtain a long life span as retribution.
There are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive a lot of illness as retribution;
there are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive little illness as retribution.ğŸ”½ There are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive an ugly appearance as retribution;
there are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive a beautiful appearance as retribution.
There are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive a small amount of power as retribution;
there are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive a great amount of power as retribution.
There are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive a low-ranking family as retribution;
there are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive a high-ranking family as retribution.
There are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive few resources as retribution;
there are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive many resources as retribution.
There are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive distorted wisdom as retribution;
there are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive correct wisdom as retribution.
There are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of hell;

there are actions that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of the animal realm;ğŸ”½Here is the text with the alignment mistakes fixed and the English translations updated to match the Sanskrit:
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of hungry ghosts;
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of asuras;ğŸ”½There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of the human realm;

There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of the desire heavens;ğŸ”½There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of the form heavens;
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of the formless heavens.
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive definite retribution;
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive indefinite retribution.ğŸ”½There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of borderlands;
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of the central regions.
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to exhaust their hellish lifespans;ğŸ”½There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to have half their hellish lifespans;
There are also karmas that can cause sentient beings to enter and exit hells temporarily.ğŸ”½There are also karmas that are created but not accumulated;
There are also karmas that are accumulated but not created;ğŸ”½...
There are also actions that are both done and accumulated;
There are also actions that are neither done nor accumulated.
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to be happy at first but suffer later;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to suffer at first but be happy later;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to suffer both at first and later;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to be happy both at first and later.
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to be poor but enjoy giving;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to be rich but stingy and greedy;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to be rich and able to give;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to be poor and stingy and greedy.
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to have physical happiness but not mental happiness;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to have mental happiness but not physical happiness;
There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to have both physical and mental happiness;

There are also actions that can cause sentient beings to have neither physical nor mental happiness.ğŸ”½Here is the text with the alignment mistakes fixed and the English translations updated to match the Sanskrit:
There are actions that can cause a being's lifespan to end but not their karma;
there are actions that can cause a being's karma to end but not their lifespan;
there are actions that can cause a being's karma and lifespan to both end;

there are actions that can cause a being's karma and lifespan to both not end, and can sever all afflictions.ğŸ”½ There are actions that can cause a being to be born in a bad realm but have an exceptionally beautiful appearance, with upright eyes and radiant skin, pleasing to behold;
there are actions that can cause a being to be born in a bad realm with an ugly appearance, rough skin, and an unpleasant visage;
there are actions that can cause a being to be born in a bad realm with a foul-smelling body and incomplete faculties.
There are beings who practice the ten unwholesome actions and receive external bad retributions;
there are beings who practice the ten wholesome actions and receive external superior retributions.
Furthermore, elder!
If there are sentient beings who pay homage to the Buddha's stÅ«pas, they will obtain ten kinds of merits;
Offering jeweled canopies, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;ğŸ”½Offering silk banners, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;
Offering bells and chimes, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;ğŸ”½Offering clothing, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;
Offering vessels and utensils, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;
Offering food and drink, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;ğŸ”½Offering shoes and boots, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;
Offering incense and flowers, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;
Offering lamps and lights, one will obtain ten kinds of merits;
Respectfully joining palms, one will obtain ten kinds of merits.
This is called the concise explanation of the Dharma door of the distinctions of worldly karmas.
The Buddha told Åšukra:
There are ten kinds of karmas that can cause sentient beings to obtain the retribution of a short lifespan:
First, killing oneself;
Second, encouraging others to kill;
Third, praising the methods of killing;
Fourth, rejoicing in seeing killing;
Fifth, wishing to destroy those one hates;
Sixth, being delighted to see an enemy destroyed;
Seventh, destroying others' wombs;
Eighth, teaching others to destroy;
Ninth, building temples for gods and slaughtering sentient beings;
Tenth, teaching people to fight and harm each other.
By these ten karmas, one receives the retribution of a short life.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to obtain a long life:
First, not killing oneself;
Second, encouraging others not to kill;
Third, praising not killing;
Fourth, being delighted to see others not killing;
Fifth, saving those who are being killed by skillful means;
Sixth, comforting the frightened when seeing them;
Seventh, giving fearlessness to the terrified;
Eighth, seeing those who suffer from illness, one gives rise to a compassionate mind;
Ninth, seeing those in urgent danger, one gives rise to a mind of great compassion;
Tenth, using various foods and drinks to give to sentient beings.
By these ten karmas, one obtains the reward of a long life.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to obtain the retribution of much illness:
First, one likes to beat and strike all sentient beings;
Second, one encourages others to beat;
Third, one praises the method of beating;
Fourth, one rejoices upon seeing beating;
Fifth, one torments one's parents, causing them mental anguish;
Sixth, one torments the sages;
Seventh, upon seeing an enemy who is sick and suffering, one greatly rejoices;
Eighth, upon seeing an enemy who has recovered from illness, one feels unhappy;
Ninth, for an enemy who is sick, one gives improper medicine;
Tenth, one eats again before the previous food has been digested.
By these ten karmas, one obtains the retribution of much illness.
There are also ten kinds of karma that can cause sentient beings to obtain a body with few illnesses:
First, not delighting in beating and striking any sentient beings;
Second, encouraging others not to beat;
Third, praising the method of not beating;
Fourth, seeing those who do not beat, giving rise to joy in the mind;
Fifth, making offerings to parents and the sick;
Sixth, seeing the sick and virtuous ones, attending to and making offerings to them;
Seventh, seeing the sick healed, giving rise to joy in the mind;
Eighth, seeing the sick and suffering, giving them good medicine, and also encouraging others to give;
Ninth, giving rise to a compassionate mind towards the sick and suffering sentient beings;
Tenth, being able to control one's food and drink.
By these ten karmas, one obtains a body with few illnesses.
There are also ten kinds of karma that can cause sentient beings to obtain an ugly and repulsive body:ğŸ”½First, delighting in anger;
Second, delighting in harboring resentment;
third, deceiving others;
fourth, disturbing sentient beings;
fifth, having no love and respect for one's parents;
sixth, not giving rise to reverence for the sages;
seventh, encroaching on and stealing the fields and livelihoods of the sages;
eighth, extinguishing the lamps in the Buddha's stÅ«pas;
ninth, despising and looking down on the ugly;
tenth, engaging in various evil deeds.
By these ten karmas, one obtains the retribution of an ugly appearance.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to obtain a handsome appearance:
first, not being angry;
second, giving clothing;
third, loving and respecting one's parents;
fourth, respecting the sages;
fifth, adorning the Buddha's stÅ«pas;
sixth, sprinkling and sweeping the halls and houses;
seventh, sprinkling and sweeping the monks' grounds;
eighth, sprinkling and sweeping the Buddha's stÅ«pas;
Ninth, seeing those who are ugly, do not despise them, but give rise to a respectful mind;
Tenth, seeing those who are beautiful, understand their past causes.
By these ten karmas, one obtains the reward of being well-proportioned.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to obtain the retribution of little power and influence:
First, giving rise to a jealous mind towards all sentient beings;ğŸ”½Second, feeling agitated when seeing others gain benefits;
Third, feeling joyful when seeing others lose benefits;
Fourth, giving rise to a jealous and malicious mind towards others' fame and praise;
Fifth, feeling greatly delighted when seeing others lose their fame and praise;
Sixth, turning away from the mind of enlightenment and destroying Buddha images;
Seventh, having no intention to serve one's parents and sages;
Eighth, encouraging others to cultivate karma that results in little power and influence;
Ninth, obstructing others from cultivating karma that results in great power and influence;
Tenth, feeling contempt towards those with little power and influence.
By these ten kinds of actions, one obtains a small amount of power and influence.
There are also ten kinds of actions that can cause sentient beings to obtain a great amount of power and influence:
First, having no jealousy towards sentient beings;
Second, giving rise to joy upon seeing others obtain benefits;ğŸ”½Third, giving rise to a compassionate mind upon seeing others lose benefits;
Fourth, giving rise to delight upon seeing others gain fame;
Fifth, assisting and comforting those who have lost their fame;
Sixth, giving rise to the bodhi mind, creating Buddha images, and offering jeweled canopies;
Seventh, respectfully welcoming one's parents and sages;
Eighth, encouraging others to abandon actions that lead to little power and influence;
Ninth, encouraging others to cultivate actions that lead to great power and influence;
Tenth, not looking down on those who lack power and influence.
By these ten kinds of actions, one obtains a great amount of power and influence.
There are also ten kinds of actions that can cause sentient beings to obtain a low social status:
First, not knowing how to respect one's father;
Second, not knowing how to respect one's mother;
Third, not knowing how to respect Å›ramaá¹‡as;
Fourth, not knowing how to respect brÄhmaá¹‡as;
Fifth, not revering the elders;
Sixth, not offering hospitality to the teachers and elders;
Seventh, not welcoming and inviting the elders to sit when seeing them;
Eighth, not following the teachings of one's parents;
Ninth, not accepting the teachings of the sages;
Tenth, despising the lower clans.
By these ten karmas, one receives the retribution of a low-ranking clan.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of a high-ranking clan:
First, skillfully knowing how to respect one's father;
Second, skillfully knowing how to respect one's mother;
Third, skillfully knowing how to respect Å›ramaá¹‡as;
Fourth, skillfully knowing how to respect brÄhmaá¹‡as;
Fifth, respecting and protecting the elders;
Sixth, welcoming the teachers and elders;
Seventh, seeing elders, welcoming and inviting them to sit;
Eighth, respecting and receiving teachings from parents;
Ninth, respecting and receiving teachings from sages;
Tenth, not despising low-ranking clans.
By these ten actions, one receives the reward of a high-ranking clan.
There are also ten actions that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of few resources;
First, stealing oneself;
Second, encouraging others to steal;
Third, praising stealing;
Fourth, rejoicing when seeing stealing;
Fifth, reducing one's parents' livelihood;
Sixth, encroaching on the resources of sages;
Seventh, not rejoicing when seeing others gain benefits;
Eighth, obstructing others from gaining benefits and creating difficulties for them;
Ninth, having no joy when seeing others giving;
Tenth, seeing famine in the world, not feeling pity but rejoicing.
By these ten kinds of actions, one will receive the retribution of little wealth.
There are also ten kinds of actions that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of much wealth:
First, oneself refraining from stealing;
Second, encouraging others not to steal;
Third, praising those who do not steal;
Fourth, rejoicing in one's heart upon seeing others not stealing;
Fifth, providing for one's parents;
Sixth, providing for sages and saints;
Seventh, rejoicing in one's heart upon seeing others gaining benefits;
Eighth, assisting those who seek benefits with skillful means;
Ninth, rejoicing in one's heart upon seeing those who delight in giving;
Tenth, feeling compassion upon seeing famine in the world.
By these ten kinds of actions, one will receive the retribution of much wealth.
There are also ten kinds of actions that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of wrong knowledge:
First, being unable to consult with wise Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as;
Second, revealing and explaining evil dharmas;
Third, being unable to uphold and practice the true Dharma;
Fourth, praising non-concentrated dharmas as being concentrated dharmas;
Fifth, being stingy with the Dharma and not explaining it;
Sixth, associating with false wisdom;
Seventh, distancing oneself from correct wisdom;
Eighth, praising wrong views;
Ninth, abandoning correct views;
Tenth, seeing foolish and evil people, despising and slandering them.
By these ten karmas, one receives the retribution of false wisdom.
There are also ten karmas that can enable sentient beings to attain the retribution of correct wisdom:
First, being able to consult with wise Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as;
Second, revealing and explaining good dharmas;
Third, hearing and upholding the true Dharma;
Fourth, seeing the explanation of concentrated dharmas and praising it as excellent;
Fifth, delighting in explaining the true Dharma;
Sixth, associating with people of correct wisdom;
Seventh, protecting and upholding the true Dharma;
Eighth, diligently cultivating much learning;
Ninth, staying far away from wrong views;
Tenth, seeing foolish and evil people, not giving rise to contempt.
By these ten karmas, one attains the retribution of right wisdom.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to attain the retribution of hell:
First, physically committing grave evil karma;
Second, verbally committing grave evil karma;
Third, mentally committing grave evil karma;
Fourth, giving rise to the view of annihilation;
Fifth, giving rise to the view of permanence;
Sixth, giving rise to the view of no cause;
Seventh, giving rise to the view of no action;
Eighth, giving rise to the view of nonexistence;
Ninth, giving rise to the view of extremes;
Tenth, not knowing how to repay kindness.
By these ten karmas, one attains the retribution of hell.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to attain the retribution of animals:
First, physically committing middling evil karma;
Second, verbally committing middling evil karma;ğŸ”½...
Third, evil karma committed by mental actions;ğŸ”½Fourth, evil karma arising from the afflictions of greed;
Fifth, evil karma arising from the afflictions of anger;
Sixth, evil karma arising from the afflictions of delusion;
Seventh, reviling sentient beings;
Eighth, harming sentient beings;
Ninth, giving impure things;
Tenth, engaging in sexual misconduct.
By these ten karmas, one receives the retribution of being an animal.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of being a hungry ghost:
First, committing minor evil karma with the body;
Second, committing minor evil karma with the speech;
Third, committing minor evil karma with the mind;
Fourth, giving rise to much greed;
Fifth, giving rise to evil greed;
Sixth, jealousy;
Seventh, wrong views;
Eighth, when one's life ends, one loves and clings to one's possessions;
Ninth, dying of hunger;
tenth, dying of thirst.
By these ten karmas, one receives the retribution of hungry ghosts.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of asuras:
first, committing minor evil deeds with the body;
second, committing minor evil deeds with the mouth;
third, committing minor evil deeds with the mind;
fourth, arrogance;
fifth, self-conceit;
sixth, conceit;
seventh, great conceit;
eighth, wrong conceit;
ninth, excessive conceit;
tenth, turning one's wholesome roots towards the asura realm.
By these ten karmas, one receives the retribution of asuras.
There are also ten karmas that can cause sentient beings to receive the retribution of the human realm:
first, not killing;
second, not stealing;ğŸ”½third, not engaging in sexual misconduct;
fourth, not lying;
fifth, not engaging in frivolous speech;
sixth, not engaging in divisive speech;
Seventh, not speaking harshly;
Eighth, not being greedy;
Ninth, not being angry;
Tenth, not having wrong views.
If one is incomplete in the ten wholesome actions, one will receive the karmic retribution of the human realm through these ten actions.
There are also ten actions that can cause sentient beings to obtain the heavenly rewards of the desire realm, namely, fully practicing the superior ten wholesome deeds.

There are also ten actions that can cause sentient beings to obtain the heavenly rewards of the form realm, namely, practicing the contaminated ten wholesome deeds, which are in accord with concentration.
There are also four actions that can cause sentient beings to obtain the heavenly rewards of the formless realm:
First, transcending all notions of form, extinguishing notions of resistance, and entering the concentration of the sphere of space;
Second, transcending all concentrations of the sphere of space and entering the concentration of the sphere of consciousness;
Third, transcending all concentrations of the sphere of consciousness and entering the concentration of the sphere of nothingness;
Fourth, transcending the concentration of the sphere of nothingness and entering the concentration of neither perception nor non-perception.
By these four kinds of karma, one obtains the retribution of the formless heavens.
There is also karma that can cause sentient beings to obtain definite retribution.
If a person, with an enhanced mind, gives to the Buddha, Dharma, Sangha, and those who uphold the precepts, and dedicates the merit and virtue of this good karma with a vow, they will then be reborn.
This is called karma with definite retribution.
There is also karma that can cause sentient beings to obtain indefinite retribution.
If karma is not done with an enhanced mind, is not cultivated further, and does not dedicate the merit and virtue with a vow to be reborn, this is called karma with indefinite retribution.
There is also karma that can cause sentient beings to obtain the retribution of the borderlands.

If karma is not given with an enhanced mind to the Buddha, Dharma, Sangha, those who uphold the precepts, and the great assembly, and one vows to be reborn in the borderlands with this wholesome root,
because of this vow, one will be reborn in the borderlands and receive pure and impure retribution.
There is also karma that can cause sentient beings to obtain the retribution of the central country.
If one performs an action, with utmost sincerity and respect, making offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, Sangha, those who uphold pure precepts, and the great assembly,
and with this wholesome root, definitely makes a vow to be reborn in a central country, one will then encounter the Buddha, hear the true Dharma, and receive the pure and supreme karmic retribution.
There is also an action that can cause sentient beings to exhaust their life span in hell:

If there are sentient beings who have already created the karma for hell, without shame or remorse, not becoming disgusted with it, with no fear in their minds, on the contrary giving rise to joy, and not repenting, but further creating heavy evil karma, like Devadatta and others,
because of this karma, they will exhaust their life span in hell.
There is also an action that can cause sentient beings to fall into hell, dying halfway, not exhausting their life span:
If there are sentient beings who create hellish karma, accumulate it, and later become fearful, ashamed, disgusted, repent, and abandon it, but not with superior intention,
because of this karma, they will fall into hell;
but because they later regret it, their life in hell will be cut short, not lasting to the end.
There is also karma that can cause sentient beings to fall into hell, but they will enter and immediately leave:

If there are sentient beings who create hellish karma, but after creating it, they become fearful, arouse superior faith, give rise to a sense of shame, detest and abandon it, repent earnestly, and do not commit it again like King AjÄtaÅ›atru's crime of killing his father, they will briefly enter hell and then be liberated.
Then the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If a person creates grave offenses and deeply reproaches themselves after committing them,
repenting and not creating them again can uproot the fundamental karma.
There is also karma that is created but not accumulated:

If there are sentient beings who commit evil deeds with their body, speech, or mind, but after committing them, they are afraid, ashamed, and turn away from them, deeply regretting and not repeating them, this is called doing but not accumulating.
There is also karma that is accumulated but not done:
If there are sentient beings who do not commit the karma themselves, but because of an evil mind, encourage others to do evil, this is called accumulating but not doing.
There is also karma that is both done and accumulated:

If there are sentient beings who commit various karmas, and their minds have no remorse, and they continue to commit them, and also encourage others to do so, this is called both doing and accumulating.
There is also karma that is neither done nor accumulated:
If there are sentient beings who do not commit karma themselves, nor teach others to do indeterminate karma, this is called neither doing nor accumulating.
There is also karma that is initially pleasant but later painful:
If there are sentient beings who are encouraged by others to joyfully practice giving, but the mind of giving is not firm, and later they regret it,
Due to these causes and conditions, they are reborn among humans, first enjoying wealth and happiness, but later falling back into poverty and suffering.
This is called first happiness and later suffering.
There is also karma that is first suffering and later happy:
If there are sentient beings who are encouraged by others to give a little with reluctance, and after giving, they are joyful without stingy regrets.
Due to these causes and conditions, they are reborn among humans, first experiencing poverty and suffering, but later returning to wealth and happiness.
This is called first suffering and later happy.
There is also karma that is first suffering and later suffering:
If there are sentient beings who are separated from good spiritual friends, with no one encouraging them, and they are unable to practice generosity even a little.

Due to these causes and conditions, they are reborn among humans, first experiencing poverty and suffering, and later returning to poverty and suffering. This is called first suffering and later suffering.
There is also karma that is first happy and later happy:
If there are sentient beings who are close to good spiritual friends, encouraged to practice generosity, and then give rise to joy, firmly cultivating the practice of giving.
For this reason, they are reborn among humans, initially wealthy and happy, and later also wealthy and happy.
There is also the karma of being poor but happy to give:
If there are sentient beings who have previously practiced giving but have not encountered a field of blessings, they will transmigrate through birth and death, in the human realm.
Because they have not encountered a field of blessings, their karmic rewards are meager and exhausted as soon as they are obtained;
But because they are accustomed to giving, even though they are poor, they are able to practice giving.
There is also the karma of being wealthy but stingy and greedy:
If there are sentient beings who have never practiced giving, but encounter a good friend, temporarily practice giving once, and encounter a good field of blessings,
Because the field is excellent, they have abundant resources for living, but because they have not been accustomed to it, they are stingy even though they are wealthy.
There is also the karma of being wealthy and able to give:
If there are sentient beings who encounter a good friend, cultivate the practice of giving extensively, and encounter a good field of blessings,
For this reason, they become extremely wealthy, have abundant resources, and are able to practice giving.
There is also karma that causes one to be poor and stingy:
If a sentient being is separated from good spiritual friends and no one encourages them, they are unable to practice giving.

Because of these causes and conditions, they are reborn in poverty and become even more stingy.ğŸ”½There is also karma that causes sentient beings to have physical happiness but not mental happiness, like ordinary beings with blessings.
There is also karma that causes sentient beings to have mental happiness but not physical happiness, like arhats without blessings.
There is also karma that causes sentient beings to have both physical and mental happiness, like arhats with blessings.
There is also karma that causes sentient beings to have neither physical nor mental happiness, like ordinary beings without blessings.
There is also karma that causes sentient beings' lives to end but their karma not to be exhausted:
If a sentient being dies in hell and is reborn in hell again, or in the realms of animals, hungry ghosts, humans, gods, or asuras, this is called life ending but karma not being exhausted.
There is also karma that causes beings' karma to be exhausted but their lives not to be exhausted:

If there are beings who experience suffering after the exhaustion of pleasure, and experience pleasure after the exhaustion of suffering, this is called the exhaustion of karma but not the exhaustion of life.
There is also karma that causes beings' karma and lives to be exhausted:
If there are beings who, after ceasing in the hells, are reborn as animals, hungry ghosts, humans, gods, or asuras, this is called the exhaustion of both karma and life.
There is also karma that causes beings' karma and lives to be both inexhaustible:
If there are beings who exhaust all afflictions, namely stream-enterers, once-returners, non-returners, and arhats, this is called the inexhaustibility of both karma and life.
There is also karma that causes beings, although born in evil destinies, to have a distinctive and wondrous appearance, with upright eyes, radiant skin and flesh, and to be liked by people when seen:

If there are sentient beings who, due to the afflictions of desire, commit offenses leading to breaking the precepts, due to this cause and condition, although they are born in the evil realms, their appearance is exceptionally wonderful, their eyes are upright and beautiful, their skin is lustrous, and people enjoy seeing them.
There are also karmic actions that can cause sentient beings to be born in the evil realms, with an ugly appearance, rough skin, and people not enjoying seeing them:

If there are sentient beings who, due to the afflictions of anger, commit offenses leading to breaking the precepts, due to this cause and condition, they are born in the evil realms, with an ugly appearance, rough skin, and people not enjoying seeing them.
There are also karmic actions that can cause sentient beings to be born in the evil realms, with a foul smell from their bodies and mouths and incomplete faculties:

If there are sentient beings who, due to the afflictions of delusion, commit offenses leading to breaking the precepts, due to this cause and condition, they are born in the evil realms, with a foul smell from their bodies and mouths and incomplete faculties.
There are also ten karmic actions that result in external evil retributions:

If sentient beings frequently practice the ten unwholesome actions, it will cause all external objects to be incomplete.ğŸ”½First, due to the karma of killing, it causes the external environment, the great earth, to become salty and bitter, and medicinal herbs to lose their potency;
Second, due to the karma of stealing, it causes external frost, hail, locusts, and other such things, leading to famines in the world;
Third, due to the karma of sexual misconduct, it causes evil winds and rains, as well as dust and dirt;
Fourth, due to the karma of false speech, it causes the external objects that are born to all be foul-smelling;
Fifth, due to the karma of divisive speech, it causes the external great earth to be high and low, uneven, with steep cliffs, deep valleys, stumps, and brambles;
Sixth, due to the karma of harsh speech, it causes the external environment that is born to be full of tiles, stones, sand, gravel, coarse and rough evil things that cannot be touched or approached;
Seventh, due to the karma of frivolous speech, it causes the external environment that is born to be full of dense forests, branches, and thorny vines;
Eighth, due to greedy karma, it causes the external retribution of making the seeds and fruits of crops subtle;
Ninth, due to hateful karma, it causes the external retribution of making the fruits of trees bitter and astringent;
Tenth, due to wrong views karma, it causes the external retribution of making crops unfruitful and harvests meager.
These ten karmas result in external evil retributions.
There are also ten karmas that result in external superior retributions:
If sentient beings cultivate the ten good karmas, which are the opposite of the above, they will obtain the ten external superior retributions.
If sentient beings pay homage to Buddha stupas, they will attain ten kinds of merits:
First, they will obtain a wonderful appearance and a beautiful voice;
Second, whatever they say, people will all believe and submit;
Third, they will be fearless in assemblies;
Fourth, devas and humans will love and protect them;
Fifth, they will be endowed with majestic power;
Sixth, sentient beings with majestic power will all come to associate with them;
Seventh, they will always be able to draw near to the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas;
Eighth, they will possess great blessings and rewards;
Ninth, they will be reborn in the heavens upon the end of their lives;
Tenth, they will quickly realize nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits obtained from paying homage to the Buddha's stÅ«pas.
If there are sentient beings who offer jeweled canopies, they will obtain ten kinds of merits:
First, they will be like a canopy in the world, protecting sentient beings;
Second, their body and mind will be at ease, free from all afflictions;
Third, everyone will respect them and dare not look down upon them;
Fourth, they will have great authority and power;
Fifth, they will always be able to draw near to the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and those of great authority and virtue, and take them as their relatives;
Sixth, they will always become wheel-turning sage kings;
Seventh, they will always be the leaders in cultivating wholesome karma;
Eighth, they will possess great blessings and rewards;ğŸ”½Ninth, they will be reborn in the heavens upon the end of their lives;
Tenth, they will quickly realize nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits of offering jeweled canopies.
If a sentient being offers silk banners, they will attain ten kinds of merits:
First, they will be like a banner in the world, and kings, ministers, relatives, and friends will respectfully make offerings to them;
Second, they will be wealthy and free, possessing great wealth and treasures;
Third, their good reputation will spread far and wide to all directions;
Fourth, they will have an upright appearance and a long lifespan;
Fifth, they will always be steadfast in their practice in their place of birth;
Sixth, they will have a great reputation;
Seventh, they will have great authority and virtue;
Eighth, they will be born into a noble family;
Ninth, when their body perishes and their life ends, they will be reborn in the heavens;
Tenth, they will quickly realize nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits of offering silk banners.
If a sentient being offers bells and chimes, they will attain ten kinds of merits:
First, they will attain a Brahma-like voice;
Second, one will have a great reputation;
Third, one will be able to recall one's past lives;
Fourth, whatever one says, people will respect and accept it;
Fifth, one will always have a jeweled canopy to adorn oneself;
Sixth, one will have wonderful necklaces and adornments;
Seventh, one's facial features will be upright and majestic, and those who see will rejoice;
Eighth, one will be endowed with great blessings and rewards;
Ninth, one will be reborn in the heavens upon death;
Tenth, one will quickly attain nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits gained from offering bells and chimes.
If sentient beings offer clothing, they will attain ten kinds of merits:
First, one's facial features will be upright and majestic;
Second, one's skin will be smooth and delicate;
Third, dust and dirt will not stick to one's body;
Fourth, one will be born fully endowed with the finest clothing;
Fifth, one's body will be covered with wonderful bedding;
Sixth, one will be endowed with the robe of shame and remorse;
Seventh, those who see them will love and respect them;
Eighth, they will possess great wealth and treasures;
Ninth, they will be reborn in the heavens upon death;
Tenth, they will quickly attain nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits obtained from offering clothing.
If sentient beings offer vessels, they will obtain ten kinds of merits:
First, living in the world will be like a vessel;
Second, they will obtain the moisture of wholesome dharmas;
Third, they will be free from all craving;
Fourth, if they thirst and think of water, springs will gush forth;
Fifth, they will never be reborn in the realm of hungry ghosts;
Sixth, they will obtain heavenly wondrous vessels;
Seventh, they will be far removed from bad friends;
Eighth, they will possess great blessings and rewards;
Ninth, they will be reborn in the heavens upon death;
Tenth, they will quickly attain nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits obtained from offering vessels.
If sentient beings offer food and drink, they will obtain ten kinds of merits:
First, one obtains longevity;
Second, one obtains a good complexion;
Third, one obtains strength;
Fourth, one attains unobstructed eloquence;
Fifth, one obtains fearlessness;
Sixth, one is free from laziness and is respected by the assembly;
Seventh, one is loved by the people;
Eighth, one is endowed with great blessings and rewards;
Ninth, one is reborn in the heavens upon death;
Tenth, one quickly attains nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits obtained from offering food and drink.
If sentient beings offer shoes and sandals, they obtain ten kinds of merits:
First, they are endowed with wonderful vehicles;
Second, the soles of their feet are level;
Third, their feet are soft and supple;
Fourth, they are light and agile even when traveling far;
Fifth, their bodies are free from fatigue;
Sixth, when walking, thorns, pebbles, and gravel do not harm their feet;
Seventh, they obtain the power of spiritual abilities;
eighth, being endowed with all kinds of servants;
ninth, being reborn in the heavens upon death;
tenth, quickly realizing nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits gained from offering boots and shoes.
If sentient beings offer incense and flowers, they will obtain ten kinds of merits:
first, being in the world like a flower;
second, the body being free from foul odors;
third, the fragrance of blessings and precepts spreading in all directions;
fourth, wherever one is born, the nose faculty is not impaired;
fifth, surpassing the world, becoming an object of reverence;
sixth, the body always being fragrant and clean;
seventh, delighting in the true Dharma, upholding and reciting it;
eighth, being endowed with great blessings and rewards;
ninth, being reborn in the heavens upon death;
tenth, quickly realizing nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits gained from offering incense and flowers.
If sentient beings offer lamps and lights, they will obtain ten kinds of merits:
First, illuminating the world like a lamp;
Second, wherever they are born, their physical eyes are not destroyed;
Third, they attain the divine eye;
Fourth, they attain good wisdom regarding good and evil dharmas;
Fifth, they eliminate great darkness;
Sixth, they attain the illumination of wisdom;
Seventh, transmigrating in the world, they are always not in places of darkness;
Eighth, they possess great blessings and rewards;
Ninth, they are reborn in the heavens upon the end of their lives;
Tenth, they quickly realize nirvana.
These are called the ten kinds of merits attained by respectfully offering lamps.
If there are sentient beings who respectfully join their palms, they attain ten kinds of merits:
First, they attain superior blessings and rewards;
Second, they are born in a noble clan;
Third, they attain a superior and wonderful appearance;
Fourth, they attain a superior and wonderful voice;
Fifth, they attain a superior and wonderful canopy;
Sixth, they attain superior and wonderful eloquence;
seventh, attaining supreme faith;
eighth, attaining supreme precepts;
ninth, attaining supreme learning;
tenth, attaining supreme wisdom.
These are called the ten merits of respectfully joining palms.

At that time, Åšuka bowed his head to the Buddha's feet and said,
I now invite the Buddha to go to the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ« to my father's house, the elder DÄ«rghanakha's home.
May it bring long-lasting peace and happiness to my father and all sentient beings!
At that time, the World-Honored One accepted the invitation in silence for the sake of benefiting [Åšuka].
At that time, upon hearing the Buddha's teachings, Åšuka rejoiced greatly, bowed his head, and withdrew.
